awd_titl_txt: Building a Partnership in New Orleans: Paving the Way for STEM Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to serve the national need of building capacity to prepare well-qualified STEM teachers, particularly to serve high-need school districts in New Orleans, Louisiana. This project will work toward developing an innovative undergraduate degree and licensure program to address STEM teacher needs in the following foundational disciplines: Biology/Life Sciences, Chemistry, Mathematics, Computer Science, and Physics. While centered at Dillard University, the project includes partnerships with Delgado Community College and Xavier University to help plan and build capacity toward a distinctive multi-institutional curricular pathway. This pathway could encourage and support talented, diverse students to pursue K-12 STEM teaching in local high-need school districts. 

The project will establish capacity for a strong transfer pathway from Delgado Community College, a two-year urban institution, to Dillard University, an urban HBCU in New Orleans, and finally to Xavier University’s master's program for a teaching certificate. The project goals include: (1) a needs assessment for STEM teacher education in the New Orleans area, (2) the establishment of strong partnerships between the three institutions and several local high-need schools, to be identified in the planning year, and (3) the design of new STEM major courses offering a specialized teacher training emphasis and culturally responsive curriculum. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the effectiveness and retention of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit 

Major outcomes from this Noyce Capacity Building Grant include a framework for team planning and coordination between Delgado Community College, Dillard University and Xavier University to solidify agreements and communicate between partner constituents, including representatives of New Orleans Parish Schools leadership, the adjoining Jefferson Parish schools, and representatives from the targeted high needs schools (McDonogh 35 Senior High School and Fannie C. Williams Charter School in New Orleans). Work between institutions has established the Associate of Science Louisiana Transfer Degree (ASLT) in Biological Sciences at Delgado Community College. 

  

In addition, an assessment of teacher issues in New Orleans was conducted, including an assessment of teacher conditions, shortages, charter school management, district oversight, mentorship, diversity, recruitment, retention, and teacher salaries in New Orleans. Results indicated that a multifaceted school-centric or local approach must be adapted in system that is almost 100 percent charter school-managed. In this highly decentralized system, individual schools have much more authority to set salary standards and other school policy. In addition, support systems for new teachers are varied, suggesting the need for more locally structured interventions and pathways for the teaching profession. Programs that introduce mentorship and financial incentives for incoming teachers are particularly needed in this restructured urban school environment. 

 

A framework for training preservice teachers in culturally diverse teaching has been developed via our experienced teacher team: Deidra Bradley, (Principal, Robert Russa Moton Charter School – Middle School); Mavia Marsalis (Special Projects, Orleans Parish School Board/Mathematics Teacher); Christine F. Mitchell, and Tamara L. Warner, (Executive Director of Curriculum and Instruction, Orleans and Jefferson Parish Public Schools). 

 

Broader Outcomes 

This Noyce Capacity Building Project has built strong partnerships with the targeted high needs schools in New Orleans. Teacher communities of interest involve both Orleans Parish Schools and Jefferson Parish Schools. In particular this program has established connections with Fannie C. Williams Charter School (preK-8), and McDonogh 35 Senior High School, two high needs schools serving African American students. In particular, McDonogh 35 was established as the first high school for African Americans in New Orleans. In addition to building a partnership between two prominent HBCUs in New Orleans, this program has laid the groundwork for developing a student recruitment pipeline from a community college that serves a large proportion of Hispanic students.  

 


Last Modified: 02/06/2024
Modified by: Ruby Broadway
